commentBody: Diabolical
Hard one with lots of old names and words, at least to this mid-thirty year old. Somehow was able to fight my way through it.

While this can be gleaned from the constructor notes about “one way rebus,” if solving on a device you do not need to use the rebus key ever for this puzzle. 

Terrific fun!!!!!!

"You're not taking paintings anymore?"
"No, I just have heist standards."

("Okay, swipe right.")

This took me 20 minutes above my average time and it was a *battle*. I had to use the Check feature at the end because I was too tired to figure out where my mistakes were. Grueling puzzle but I really enjoyed solving it.
Sorry. No fun at all. I still don’t understand whether I need to use the rebus key in order for the online puzzle to work.
Well, it was very difficult but extremely clever! 65D I have only seen spelled as femmes.

Did not love it.  I think it was technically interesting...But i think the mechanics of solving it sucked the life out of it.   Meaning...that having to search the clue list to find which Across had a word needed for a Down just was tedious and wasnt any fun.   

If it was possible to circle or highlight the relevant artists and squares which were needed in other parts of the puzzle it would have lower the "arrrrrghghhhh this is annoying" factor.
Brilliant, but really fun.
I didn’t enjoy it at all.
Very difficult puzzle. May be deemed clever, however, too complex for me. Many of the newer puzzle seem to rely on puns and other tricks. Very disappointing.
Always up for a rebus puzzle.  But it has to be consistent across and down.  Unlike this one.

What a brain melter! 
While muttering “Mary had a little lamb” over and over to try to understand this extra letter business, I went through some stages (h/t AudreyLM):

TACTICS: keep track who goes where
SLALOM: kept losing track of same
SNERD: felt less intelligent than him at this point
RADISHES: as in, radishes for brains
GETS WISE: what finally happened 

My brain, exhausted by this fun challenge, will return to its usual state by and by.
Fems …. really?
Clever, but not very logically consistent.  Pretty much the epitome of clever… if this puzzle was a political candidate, it would definitely be a Democrat who lost a race it should have won.
Oof, rough solve. The rebuses don't check their cross entries, so it ended up just being a guess at the end.

Really struggling with how the corresponding entries only highlight one way and not the other. It's taking me forever just to find the entry I'm looking for. Seems like a simple formatting thing that could have been fixed.

What an artfully clever theme! You would expect nothing less from David Kwong. 

I wish the entries with the stolen letters also highlighted their corresponding artist entries. That would have made it easier to follow. 

Finding phrases that contained  O’KEEFFE and SARGENT is most impressive. 

Great puzzle! Thanks, David.
I appreciate the hard work that went into this, but a crossword should not need that many instructions. Not for me.

I don't believe the Model A was the first Ford car. The Model T was introduced in 1908, and the Model A was introduced in 1927. https://blueprintengines.com/blogs/news/the-ford-model-a-a-brief-history#:~:text=The%20Ford%20Model%20A%20was,Commercial
Wait, so who stole the paintings? DON'T LEAVE US HANGING, DAVID!

The constructor knows how to bring da ruckus! This puzzle is for the children.


IYKYN.
(I do wish I had read the instructions first, though).
Thanks. Way to blow up my Sunday average.

This is probably an overreaction but this was hands down the most frustrating puzzle I've solved this year. I appreciate what the constructor was trying to achieve with the theme but the mechanics of it just didn't work for me. A lot of the fill was way too obscure and seemed like it was largely software generated. The multiple proper nouns and Naticks didn't help either. Lastly - the way the Notes section was worded (I assume by the editors) was more confusing than helpful and really made me question my proficiency with the English language. /endrant

About as much fun

as a root canal, without

anesthesia
Thank you David Kwong, puzzles that play with the crossword format are always my favorite! There's artistic references and even a bit of meta magic in there, absolutely brilliant!
First of all this said "paintings" rather than painters, so at first I was looking for titles of famous paintings. Finally solved it but overall a big mess and not fun at all.

Sheesh. Tough one, but very clever and satisfying. Lots of talking out loud to myself, e.g., "The downs are always correct. The stray letter is always in the across...," like that. I print it out to do in pen, so there were no italics in the print version. I had to slog through the list and circle every pair after a while because I kept going around and around--I can't imagine having to do that on a phone or on the electronic version. Will look up the Kwong's archived puzzles, though. Challenges ahead!
When I’m using the puzzle app, why can’t I learn what the theme of the puzzle is? How/where can I learn what the theme is? Is there a pdf version I’d have to print out?

That was tough and 20 minutes over my Sunday average but I did enjoy the workout.  I actually caught on to the theme and the rebuses (rebi?) but it was really hard to keep track of everything online.  "So wait ... that one ties in where?"  I've never gone up and down the clues so much in a puzzle!  Figured out "I WAS FRAMED" and that helped me see a couple that I missed.  But I had a bigger challenge from the many words and names I'd never heard of, some intersecting, and a crucial misspelling of "OKEEFFE" in a rebus that took ages to find due to it being in a micro-sized font on my laptop.
85D / 109A is a pretty frustrating Nattick.  I've never heard of a Snerd, and I'm not familiar with Darien.  Other than that single square though, I thoroughly enjoyed this puzzle.
Holy Grandma Moses that was Monet-mentally difficult.
Glad I'm in the majority here. Awful mechanics here since it was impossible to reference backwards. Even including the corresponding clue number would have been enough
Super clever and fun. Thank you!
Alas, this one was not for me.  I can’t recall the last time I failed to finish a puzzle, but now it’s today.  Too frustrating.
Regarding the Ford models, the clue is correct. Expand my comments by clicking read more here https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=12/15/2024

The constructor wrote in his notes “I was desperate to make those two phrases work.”

For me, this should have been a sign that perhaps you were trying too hard.  Things done from a state of desperation tend not to work out well.
no internal logic. hated it. a painting is a painting and a painter is a painter and if the theme takes a paragraph to explain you're doing it wrong.

Actors, towns, brands, tv channels, politicians. This already makes it hard for foreigners to solve but add to that not only a rebus but one that doesn't work across and down and it becomes a pain. Hated it
Ugh. What a contrived theme.  Did not care for this one.

It is very rare that I dislike a puzzle so much I no longer care about the solution. I appreciate the daring attempt but the execution was very clunky on many levels. The best puzzles on this conceal how hard they are to make. The glue needed to paste the theme together was glaring. This doesn't belong at the Met. It barely belongs on grandma's refrigerator.

Got through it, but never felt the satisfying "aha" from it. The missing back references or co-highlighting to show the corresponding artist fill when you highlighted one of the words with missing letters was a major editing mistake in my mind.

Moreover, the fact that the "extra" letter in a couple of of the key fills was, itself, part of a tricky down fill (Model A or T? The C-What? Fems, Dems, THems, ...?? Wu-Tang??) and that you couldn't use the across fill to validate your guess, meant that decrypting the 10-letter "evidence" wasn't so much a punny reward for solving the puzzle as a necessary part of the punishment to finish it.

This just seemed to be too clever by half. If it had been done without the extra letters for the "evidence," I think this would've been a solid puzzle. But one gimmick too many ruined this one for me.

I feel bad saying this, because I’m sure people worked hard to make this puzzle. But it was such an unpleasant experience that I need to voice my opinion:

I really didn’t like it at all.

I think part of the issue was that the across clues didn’t highlight the relevant downs. So, I was constantly trying to figure out which down was supposed to go with which across. On top of that, one letter in the across answers was irrelevant to the down which made it impossible to read.

Then, while it was cute to run with the theme of “stolen” letters. The remaining across fills really should have been actual words. 

Just really something I hope to never see again. This was a bad idea.

I think just the first level of creativity would have been great. Some missing letters and you find them elsewhere. All the additional stuff on top of that detracted from the fun (the I was framed etc was not needed) and messed up being able to read clues both ways.
Reading the comments - Glad I'm not alone.  I read the wordplay explanation and still don't get it.  What???  Why???

Art heist.  The only thing stolen was my streak.  I got the artists part, but how to get the boxes that replaced the artist names was impossible unless you're a mind reader.

I'm on the NYT app on a tablet.  I see no puzzle title or see any description for the puzzle.  How am I supposed to solve this?

enjoyed the theme and didn’t so much mind the fact that the puzzle refers to artists as paintings, but honestly so many aspects of this puzzle weren’t thought through properly. i filled in a bunch of artist names based on crosses before figuring out the conceit of the puzzle and then had to scour the puzzle to find the names again to try to figure out what the missing letters were, why not have both clues refer to each other? add to that multiple naticks and a rebus that doesn’t work both ways and the solving experience was just frustrating

Since comments are moderated for content, I’ll  keep it civil and simply say that I solved it, but I did not enjoy it. In fact, I found it contrived, annoying and completely unsatisfying. I feel let down and maybe even a little angry 😂
I wish the linked clues were cross-referenced in both directions because i had to spend a lot of time scrolling through all the clues to find the other pair.
Kwong is clever, but he's narrow-minded when it comes to feedback, and my guess is that Joel tried to tell him

Even with all these explanations about the missing letters, rebuses(rebii??) etc etc, it is not clear to me whether we the 10 "clue cells" require us to enter the "clue" letter and then the artist's name, or whether we are supposed to just enter the clue letter, or whether those 10 cells are not actually rebuses at all. I am NOT able to get this crossword to solve. NOT FAIR.  I have all the "answers" I just can't figure out how to enter it so that the puzzle is "solved".
Looking forward to a nice Monday
Easily the most irritating crossword ever.

If I ever cancel my subscription to the NYT crossword it'll be because of a trainwreck puzzle like this. I've got a lot of it finished but I think that I'm just going to quit. I despise losing a nice streak because of this tedious and nonsensical --- better not continue (emu).

I think Jim Horne at xwordinfo.com shows the solved puzzle in a very clear way. You can see where the artists are and what the Down words are. Thanks, Jim. https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=12/15/2024 I didn't have trouble with any of the fill, but as many as have already noted, I had trouble locating where each artist was supposed to go after I found them. It was somewhat headache inducing.

For those, like Barry Ancona, who thought that the little yellow numbers made the Thursday puzzle too easy, this one is an apt response, as it made you search for the corresponding place with missing artist. I lost track of where I was supposed to insert "Titian" for example, but had "Titian" been highlighted had I clicked on the spaces for "Registered Dietitian" that would have made it too easy, too like this week's Thursday puzzle. The other weird thing is that I didn't rebus-enter "O'Keeffe" into "Smoke Effects" but just filled it in as "Smacts" and I STILL got the gold star! (Kept on thinking WTH is "Smacts"? Some portmanteau?) On balance, I prefer this puzzle over Thursday for precisely that reason, rugged individualist that I am, here. 

But look at all the top comments: nary a positive review among them! Bunch o' thumbsuckers! 

My quibbles with this puzzle are specific words and even then, it's just that my eyebrows raised and then lowered at either clues or answers for
(especially) FEM -- there are more benign ways to clue this --
TOY MEN  -- huh?
REAVES -- what the!
FLAM -- oh come on!
MODEL A's -- Ford (a vicious anti-semite who believed in and promoted "The Protocols of the Elders of Zion") first built Model A's, then the more successful Model T's, then in the mid 1920s, started making what he called "Model A's" which confused everyone. Ford also believed Jews created jazz to corrupt society, and suggested square dancing as a viable alternative.

On the app, this one definitely needed more cues.  The artists and the stolen lines needed to both be highlighted.  

Also some tip to indícate how to handle the rebus squares, since having an “A” in the middle of “buenos aires argenAina” makes no sense, framed or not

Just a general comment: it seems as though the Times is publishing the next day's puzzles online earlier and earlier during the current day. 

I find this increasingly annoying, as I try to carve out time to get to the day's puzzles when I can. I race to the puzzles, trying to get the web pages open before the next day's puzzles get posted and when I'm too late, it feels like I've missed the cutoff time for an online credit card payment. A puzzle posting shouldn't be the cause of this sort of added time crunch stress. 

It's not the end of the world to have to go into the puzzle archives to find the current day's puzzles at 9pm, but again, I find it to be bothersome, and none of the other major papers that publish puzzles online post the following day's puzzles before midnight. 

We live in a world where the 24 news cycle moves too fast and the online front page of the NYT changes by the hour. Trying to keep up with that is bad enough without finding out that the Times has a hair trigger when it comes to publishing the puzzles, which I find to be a treasured sanctuary from the daily madness.

Please consider slowing the train down a bit and publishing the next day's puzzles closer to midnight. Or even at midnight, as is done with Connections.

I'm a little more inclined to raise an issue with the tech guys on this one, as it would have been very helpful to highlight both the "painting" and the "stolen from" when working on either, instead of just when working on the "painting". It got to be more of a problem of remembering what went where than trying to get the answers correct.

The concept was great, the construction was great, the complexity made the solving experience more exasperating than difficult.

Overall, I liked it, but it was a little too convoluted to be really enjoyable.

The basic idea was fun -- the artists were easy enough -- and many clues were good. Now, the bad part. The horizontal-only rebuses, combined with the orphaned letters that didn't seem to fit anywhere, defeated me. I tried answers like Kahlo/F in rebus squares. That didn't work and I didn't know what else to try. Maybe the grid was designed by Escher.

I’m with the crowd on this one.  It was an extraordinarily clever puzzle, and I very much wanted to enjoy it. As is my WONT, I solved without paying much attention to the theme.  I caught on pretty quickly to the notion that the stolen painting clues were artists names and just started entering them when the crosses made the identity clear.  I assumed that the gimmick was that those answers would be missing the painter’s names, but I didn’t bother to check.  So whenever an answer appeared wonky I just ignored it unless the missing artist came immediately to mind.  I did find the unchecked letters somewhat annoying because they made the already mangled acrosses even more gibberishy.  I probably would have been ok with it, but I had a typo, and searching for it with all the nonsensical letter streams was headache inducing.  And to boot, I completely missed that the unchecked letters spelled IWASFRAMED.  TLDR: loved the concept. disliked the execution.

On another note, the puzzle put me in mind of a very fine book called The Art Thief by Michael Finkel.  It tells the story of Stephane Breitwieser, who pulled off an incredible series of art thefts in amazingly low tech fashion, and just kept the art in the attic apartment he shared with his accomplice girlfriend. The book marks a comeback of sorts for Finkel, whose career was long sidetracked by a plagiarism scandal, which gave him a certain affinity for his subject.  It’s a lively and entertaining read.
Having the "S" remain after the Degas is stolen is incorrect and confusing. I thought that was the pattern until it wasn't. Not a perfect puzzle.

Yeah, the idea was clever, but the solving experience in the app ruined it and made it way too fussy and hard. Took nearly twice as long as my typical Sunday.

Like others, I got the idea early, but just could not figure out how the puzzle wanted the theme crossings entered.

I was pleased that I knew all of the artists, but putting them in the squares from which they had been "stolen" and then trying to understand why that didn't work was an exercise in frustration.

Caitlins explanation, "Remove M-O-N-E-T, and at the spot between FRO and OTEN, leave the crossing letter from 49-Down — [On dry ground], or ASHORE — in place to make FROROTEN," was no help. That's what I had before I entered the "stolen" painters. 

I suspect that David Kwong and his accomplices had a lot more fun constructing this puzzle than I did trying to solve it.

Streak broken, but life is too short to worry about that—at least mine is.

The rebus squares should have been circles, as per usual practice.  Also, I feel that there was less here than meets the eye.  You fill in the names of famous artists.  That's it.  Am i missing something?
This was the holiday fruitcake of puzzles. While I admire the effort and cleverness that went into it, there is much too much going on for it to be enjoyable to those partaking of it.

It’s all been said before, so I’ll just add that this was the most unenjoyable NYT Xword I’ve ever tried to do. I got part of the theme but the fill-in letters made gibberish entries. I gave up and read the column. Still not finished. Yechh!

Enjoyed it overall, but agree with others that the highlighting should've worked both ways (not the fault of the constructor, I assume). Also, OREL x LEHAR and SNERD x DARIEN were very tricky crosses, in my opinion!

can someone please tell us how to enter the rebus? We've been fighting with the puzzle for over an hour, trying all the possibilities
1. Only the across artist, e.g. "ERNST"
2. Only the missing down letter, "I"
3. Artist first "ERNST/I"
4. Letter first "I/ERNST"
I love doing the Sunday puzzles.  This one, not at all.
Well, I liked it! Something different for once! Ambitious and clever!

[Dr. Seuss mode on]

I did not enjoy this puzzle. I did not enjoy it one bit. 

[Dr Seuss mode off]

I agree that there needed to be both horizontal and vertical cross-referencing. I also feel that the answer key, which I looked at after finally solving, 30-plus minutes over my average time, was misleading. It’s not helpful to show the rebuses instead of whatever letter was supposed to go in the “missing” space of each Across theme answer. The xwordinfo key was much, much, much more clear, and reminded me why I pay big bucks for xwordinfo. 

Please do better, editors. This is supposed to be entertainment, not
Torture.

Over two hours for me, and nearly half of that involved initially entering the single letters for the downs, then going back and rebusing in the painter's names, then flyspecking, then te-entering the single letters, then re-entering the painter's names again, then flyspecking some more. This was another one that startled me when the music played. 

I'm going to bed.

The fun is in the challenge, and this puzzle certainly was challenging.   The people who say they didn't like it or who gave up before finishing it seemed to be those who solve on their devices.  Maybe that's the problem.  I print the puzzle out and use pen and paper--much simpler, and you are able to get the "big picture" without endless scrolling up and down.
Thanks to David Kwong for such a clever crossword!
A fun and creative puzzle, fun solve!

This was a stone cold, ten out of ten banger. Anyone whingeing and moaning about the difficulty of the overall theme, I imagine you don’t have a lot of fun in your lives… the final reveal of the secret code was a master stroke. Loved it - took me a good while to parse it all but I loved it!

The “answer” to the puzzle has the artists in rebus form at the crossing squares but the puzzle was not “solved” unless the crossing squares had the single letter to the down clues instead of the artist rebus going across. How can the puzzle not be solved when I had the same entries as the published answer? S
35a is wrong, plain and simple.

This was a Wedding Cake puzzle, so many tiers I don’t even know how to cope.  I am in awe of the mastery it required to make this puzzle without resorting to rebuses as part of the answer. 

At one point I cleared the entire puzzle and started over.  

I discovered going through the Down clues to find the typo for the star was better than going it from Across, which I am won’t to do. 

I especially appreciated that the stolen art were names of artists. 

The cherry on top was certainly the alibi defense.  

Muah. Perfection.
Such a clever piece of construction that it almost outpaces the developers’ abilities to code it.

Love the concept, and I did start taking notes of the connections, but after half an hour I decided the reward wasn't worth the time or patience required to connect all the dots. I'm sure more experienced solvers with better memory than mine enjoyed it, but this is one that just wasn't going to to be worth it--so after completing the puzzle I just moved on. I certainly don't begrudge those that untangled the theme their pleasure, though!
A Sunday puzzle just ruined.

Don't usually comment, but have to appreciate this clever puzzle. Minor nit, the lack of highlighting of the artist clue when the clue being stolen from did make it a slower solve. My time was over 8 minutes slower than my Sunday average.

Was trying to figure out how the answer to 15-D is a "cactus-like plant."  The only thing they have in common is they are succulents. But so are begonia and hot house geraniums.  There are no areoles or spines that make a cactus a cactus.  Most cacti have no leaves while the answer has many leaves.  The answer and "cactus" are in two completely different plant families.

Guess having too much botany and horticulture experience can lead one astray.  Thanks for the "across" fills.
Decided it wasn’t worth my time or eyesight to linger over this on an iPad. Far too cutesie and littered with acronyms.
Not highlighting the artist clues when the other clues were selected is very frusturating and would have been easy to set up. The concept was very interesting, however, very poor execution.

I actually didn’t see the instructions before I did the puzzle. I had no real problem figuring out what was going on. The one big glitch was MODEL AS. Without help on the cross clues, I inserted MODEL TS. That was my big fly specking task.

To all those asking how to enter their answers. Read the instructions given and follow them. That is: remove the artists name and in the space created put the letter needed by the crossing. This letter is then checked by the phrase. I WAS FRAMED.
The artist’s name is the entered as directed by the relevant clue.
Steaen? Really? I think at least use words that someone has said at SOME point in history.
Apparently Ford made two different model A cars. Qne was their first car. Another was the successor to the Model T. This cost me my streak. grumble...grumble...grumble.

Oh man…so unfortunately unenjoyable :(( 
First of all, what a construction masterpiece this is, seriously one of the most impressive constructions I’ve seen. 

But the solving experience left a lot to be desired. I  don’t mind a puzzle being challenging or teaching me new things, but the challenges here were far from enjoyable. Eg it became quite tiring trying to find the corresponding “stolen” entry from the acrosses. Why couldn’t they be highlighted like they were in the other direction? And then at the end it took me a while to find the “replaced” squares as well, because sometimes they were correct (eg mary had a little lamb) and not obviously replaced. Couldn’t these squares have been circled or something?
Finally, the complex construction inevitably also needs to some proper noun crossings eg SNERD/DARIEN, which for me was impossible (I put a T at the crossing)

Anyway…great puzzle spoiled by unfortunate editorial decisions for the mobile version

This is one of those puzzles where you have to ask whether the torturousness of the fill is justified by the brilliance of the theme. I would say in this case a resounding yes. Again if you think this is supposed to be a rebus I remind all Sunday solvers to always check the info first. I agree with other commentators that there were some technical things that could have made the solve more enjoyable— highlighting both the artist and the location, and circling the letter added. I don’t think it would have made it too easy. I had to get a paper and pencil out. But otherwise thoroughly enjoyed the ingeniousness of it
WOW!!!! This was a delightfully complex puzzle. Thank you.
Too scattered. too ill-fitting. More like playing whack-a-mole than solving a crossword puzzle.
Very enjoyable, probably couldn't have done it without the info on the title page?  But it's really about painters not paintings, i'nnit?

Wow! This took me 40 minutes over my average Sunday time of 53 minutes but I did it! I use a laptop so the squares aren't as small as on a phone and that helped. And I did solve with the rebus in place and it gave me the chime at the end, so I guess either way was accepted. The amazing thing to me is how David Kwong came up with this idea and actually constructed such a puzzle for us. Thank you, David! I imagine it took you many more hours than it did for us solvers! Good going!

Wow, what a puzzle! I loved it. I was definitely scratching my head for a while, and I had to reread the note a few times. At first I thought these were going to be actual art heists, and I'd need to know the names of paintings and the museums or cities they were stolen from. It was a relief when I finally understood that for EAST[I]ANDARDTIME I just needed to mentally replace the I with ERNST to get the straightforward answer to the clue.

What tripped me up were some of the downs: I had Model Ts  for As, kems for fems (don't ask me why), and toyman for toy men. I ended up printing out the filled-out grid, going through the clues to find the 10 pairs, circling those extra letters, and finally writing out the phrase, which was ultimately what led me to fixing those three mistakes. Sounds like a lot of work but altogether it took me an hour and 12 minutes to finish the puzzle, which isn't unusual for me. 

I agree with the commenters who would like to have had the highlights work both ways. I did a lot of back-and-forthing - my short term memory was not up to keeping track. I solved it on a laptop, can't imagine how hard this one would be on a tiny phone screen.

Silly me, I thought most of the complaints about the puzzle would center on the note referring to stolen paintings but the answers all being the names of painters.
Deeply frustrating puzzle for all the reasons already mentioned. I blew a 146-day streak just to be done with it.

The note says "10 pieces of evidence – letters in the Downs. Read them from top to bottom to reveal a message."

I defy anyone to find any "evidence" in the published answer key.

Seems like a cover-up by the authorities.
Model A Fords were manufactured AFTER Model T's.  Check the history.
Too clever and a miserable solving experience without two-way clue highlighting on a mobile device. I solved it, but this was way too contrived and gimmicky. No enjoyment factor here.
Glad some of you liked it - but for me, way more annoying than fun.

Clever puzzle, very challenging, I'm glad I finished it.  Please never do it again.  

The concept was good, but getting the stolen paintings lined up with where they were stolen from and then keeping track of the Down letters that weren't part of the Across answers just sort of sucked the fun out of it.  I feel like I shouldn't ⁎need⁎ scratch paper to do a crossword puzzle.  Probably this would be easier on paper with a highlighter pen and multiple ink colors, but that's too much like work.
This was so far over my head it was ridiculous. I'm glad several people enjoyed it.
In the immortal words of David St. Hubbins and Nigel Tufnel, it’s such a fine line between stupid and clever — and once again, David Kwong has tried to be too clever and crossed it.
No. “Reave” alone is bad enough. But all the painting nonsense is just irritating.
Loved this one! My only complaint was 65 down - in the lesbian context, it is only spelled "femmes."

This puzzle was LAME, the constructor should have DITCHEd the idea when they realized they were "desperate to make" it work. I am EAGER to forget I spent time on solving it.  Also the answer key is a GREATLIE, what a SHAM.

OOF this was rough! Even understanding the gimmick of stolen letters, some of the fill makes nonsense words, which felt wrong. I see what was done but I just didn't enjoy the result. 

Oh well, not every puzzle is for everyone!

Unlike most, I thought this was a pretty clever little art-heist mystery hidden in the puzzle. To those complaining that the stolen answers are technically painters and not paintings, maybe it helps to recall that paintings are often referred to using the painter's name, as in, "It's a Monet." In this puzzle, think of it like this: Which painting was stolen? The Monet was stolen!!!

See? It works.

Agree though that it would have helped if the puzzle had done the linked clue highlighting in both directions. I stared at BOS for ages not realizing it was part of the thene before I finally figured out that it was linked to Degas, which I had solved much earlier before I'd realized what was happening w the theme (I fully missed the note explaining it, so it was a discovery mission for me from the start).

I am in the minority, I guess, but I loved this puzzle. At first, the missing pieces seemed impossibly mysterious. Put in the rebuses, then took them out. (I forgot to click on the I for instructions.) Finally finished (18 minutes over average), and found the “I was framed.” Great fun.

This is, without a doubt, the worst constructed puzzle you have ever published. Even if you forgive the use of rebuses (which are always bad) the down clues Do. Not. Make. Any. Sense.

Do better.

Thumbs up from me.  Clever and tricky and, in the end, solvable (at least I figured it out with no look-ups and 2 minutes longer than my Sunday average). 
I will admit that before I figured it out I was ready to grumble about it being too hard. 
I’m glad I persisted.

I am SO glad to have finished this puzzle.  Because it was simply terrible and I want to put it far, far behind me.

What a slog.  This is everything anyone ever complains about regarding gimmicked puzzles (the ones I typically love), multiplied to the point of nausea.  I dutifully filled in rebuses.  That wasn't enough.  I took the rebuses out.  Surely the down answers had to make SOME sense and keep their letters. Maybe some kind of combo rebus?  Slashes?  I finally resorted to actually reading the little "i" thing about the theme, which didn't help.  Finally after 3 flyspecking sessions I twiddled the right letter and I can put this shame of a crossword puzzle to rest.

So much for the "Sundays are Tuesday/Wednesday level" guideline.  This was an awful puzzle and I regret even starting it.

Difficulty with zero joy.  Challenging in the worst way, with unrewarding paths to unwind.  I've heard similar criticisms of his movie (haven't seen it) so maybe this tracks.  Please do not have this "constructor" back here.  Self-indulgent in the absolute worst ways, providing nothing of value or entertainment to the customer.

(emu filler)
The phrase "too clever by half" comes to mind.....might not have been so bad if the rebus function worked, but it was flaky...so in the end, just an irritating pain.
HIGHLIGHTING the connected clues in  BOTH DIRECTIONS would have made the puzzle less frustrating. Very clever, though.
I loved the puzzle, super fun! Suggestion to the editors: highlighting both entries in the pair would have helped a lot, instead of doing it in just one direction.

This was a fun puzzle in theory, but such a pain to do on the mobile app because the highlighted answers worked only one way. If they went the other way also, it would have been way easier to check how things were going without trying to keep the related answers placed in my head (not all of us have the luxury of scratch paper - I did this on a bus ride!).
What a painful mess.

Yes it was tough but I really enjoyed this puzzle - decided to solve with the “stolen artists” entered as rebuses (rebi?) to keep track more systematically. Once I was able to get the remaining squares filled correctly…TADA! The rebus squares were automatically replaced by the corresponding vertical clue letters to spell out the special message. Happy dance!

Wow!  What an incredible job the author did in creating this puzzle!  The execution of the concept was phenomenal.  From a solver's point of it was a stinker following twists and turns. Gradually the lights grew brighter and I found my way.  A strong background in art history was helpful. The most difficult Sunday puzzle I've seen in years.  A gifted constructor--a hard-earned finish.

As others mentioned here, it was a little too much to expect that solvers remember/find each artist and then match them with the appropriate Rebus. And the down answers didn't work with the names of the artists plugged in. Hopefully next week's crossword will be a bit more organized and logical.

wow, i am shocked to find so much anger and nastiness in these comments. my son and i thought this puzzle was clever, challenging, and fun. and what a feat of construction!
thank you, david kwong! we will definitely be looking up (and solving) your puzzles from the archive.

Didn't get to the puzzle till late, and when I got to Wordplay at around 12:30 and there were 204 comments, I thought, this can't be good.

What was wrong tonight?

First of all, the answer key given was misleading.  All those painters' names were stolen, so they shouldn't have been in the answer key.  In those squares, the down letters should have been there.  This confused a lot of solvers, but that wasn't the puzzle's fault.  So what was the puzzle's fault?

Well, what I find fault with is the crossing down letter.  The second I from IS INTO, for example.  We know that certain letters have been removed from the across.  But that's no reason to add an extraneous letter to the rest of the across entries.  So the down entries should have contained either:

a. a letter from the remaining across answer (that means the across answers would have been one square less, and 5D would have been something where either a T or an A (the two closest letters to the missing letters' part) belonged.  I know this is hard to explain, but 21A should just read EASTANDARDTIME, without an interloping I.  There are five letters missing, and no reason to add an errant I.

or

b. a blank space to represent the stolen letters of the across.  Thus, whatever crossed 21A would be complete in five letters instead of six, with that third space blank.  The software can handle it; it's been done before.  That would at least have made more sense.

I like hard, but this one was hard and weird.

I have solved 100s of NYT crossword puzzles, and that was the very first one I absolutely hated. If didn't have a 6-month streak going, I would have put down my phone and gone for a walk instead.

I love when a puzzle (ahem, usually Thursdays) slices out a chunk out of an answer and drops it elsewhere in the grid. When the letters left behind spell something new, that's super fun!

Having the leftovers be gibberish is less fun. Having to guess a random, unrelated letter to jam in there is not fun at all. Having to do this 10 times, because it's Sunday, is as much fun as doing taxes.

And on top of it all, the clueing was way harder than most Sundays. No thank you!

Wow, lots of strong feelings. I enjoyed it, mostly, and just accepted that it was a Thursday-level puzzle on a Sunday. I did feel sorry of the casual Sunday solver, though. Also, although there were clear links from the Artist back to the "stolen from" clue, it would have made a more easily navigated puzzle if you could have referenced the other direction. I finally used "Find" on my browser to search for the number in the page text.

I dreamt I was at a bar in Oslo sitting next to not-Tom-Hanks, coming up with ways to spell O’Keeffe and Kahlo backwards in the middle of another word. While someone suggested lame was ableist in response to a comment. And yet it felt so real.

This one warped my brain — more than 42 minutes. 

Perhaps next week I will remember to check the instructions instead of running in completely blind. 🤦🏻‍♂️

The idea of this was good. The clues were really good. The implementation was really bad. My biggest gripe was that if I had the stolen painting clue entered having figured it out from the cross-clues, I had to go search through the clues to find that one. It should have highlighted it. That alone would have made it much much better for me. 

I didn't put it in as rebus at all, did that work? but understanding that the letter where the painting was stolen from was the cross clue only was confusing. It kind of goes against what a "cross"word is, so it was completely not intuitive.

By the time I figured it all out I was too frustrated and just looked up where to fix it. I had solved everything, but had not input it correctly, and that isn't a good puzzling experience. 

But as I said, I really liked the idea, and the way the clues were done was fantastic. Just the implementation didn't work for me

I found this tough on mobile as many did, but I did eventually complete it with no hints or lookups, and generally liked the trick! It’s the first crossword all year where I’ve needed a scratch paper: if I hadn’t figured out the punny punchline, I might have never gotten all of those down entries. It’s hard because they don’t cross, but knowing there would be some “payoff” in the word they spell was at least like a mini cross. 

My only issue actually has nothing to do with the mechanics. Instead, it’s an old mainstay of the Wordplay comments section: there are a bunch of naticks in this puzzle. OREL crossing LEHAR. SNERD crossing DARIEN. OKEEFE crossing MIRO and LEANNA crossing ERNST (though those, you could argue, have extra implicit crosses inherent to the conceit of the puzzle, so I’m giving them a pass.) UMA crossing ARTE (though I have to assume everyone knew at least one of those). And that’s to say nothing of the ones that aren’t technically naticks, but had proper nouns crossing what I personally found to be very esoteric vocab: ESME crossing POTASH, LILLE crossing OLIOS.

Again, I did finish, so I’m not grumbling about impossibility. I just found the last bits somewhat of a slog, as I button mashed my way through 2 or 3 squares where I knew no lightbulb moment was forthcoming. Anyway, happy Sunday to those who managed to scrape through!

What a gimmicky piece of you-know-what this puzzle was. So you're supposed to ignore the fact the downs need a letter that makes no sense in the across, except it's called CROSSwords. Quality matters, not novelty.

It’s a shame, because this was a clever idea and with a couple of tweaks, I think I would have really enjoyed it. I get the sense that others really wanted to enjoy it, too. I won’t detail the failures in execution because they have been well covered. I will just say that  I appreciate the effort, if not the editing.

Should I be delighted to solve this puzzle, when doing so took me fifty percent longer than my usual Sunday time? I feel like this crossword addiction is unhealthy, my subscription by coincidence ends today. Will take a break and will come back in a while. 

I enjoy solving, but I am slow, and I cannot justify the over two hours spent today, a rat in a maze, just for a small piece of cheese.
What a pillow cover of a puzzle.

I have a 1256-day streak going. About the only things in life I've done with equal consistency is love my child and breathe. 

I now have a new most-hated puzzle in this streak. In order to retain the integrity of the streak, I scrupulously avoid peeking or reading commentary until after I'm done - the only exception being the occasional spellcheck. Until today. What is meant by "unusual 'one-way' rebus"? Is this some newly invented rule that it's okay for clues to make sense in one direction while being rendered into meaningless gibberish in the other? Is it not the beauty of the rebus that it must make sense in both directions? 
I was so irritated that I relented, for the first time in almost four years, and read some of the commentary. Ms. Lovinger's assessment is incorrect, at least based on my mobile device. I filled in the cross clues (eg. ISINTO) based on her directive that "it should be entered as normal". Back to the puzzle, and upon completion, I received the "So Close" message. Only after I changed those squares to the makes-sense-in-one-direction-utter-nonsense-the-other rebuses did I receive the music and reveal. Maddening and ridiculous. 

One last rant. Miro, O'Keeffe, Monet etc are painters, not paintings. AN O'Keeffe or A Monet can be stolen; you would never say to the police, "O'Keeffe was stolen!" or they might ask if you meant to report a kidnapping. 

My streak may be intact, but this is the closest I've ever come to tossing it as no longer worth it.

As an avid art student and then artist, this was right up my alley and I really enjoyed figuring out how the artists’ names fit into the phrases. My favorite was Okeeffe in smoke effects (I worked in theater too). Very satisfying Mr. Kwong… kudos from me.

Yeesh. This one was a slog, as many have already said. The poor technical implementation on mobile, the messy Across answers that spell nothing when filled in properly, the crisscrossing naticky names, the ancient clues... and then the trite revealer at the end. Ugh. 

The whole puzzle felt inelegant to me. I'm sorry to be harsh but I'm glad it's in the past.
Not worth my time

Maybe I'm just not smart enough to figure this out, but this puzzle is beyond impossible for me. Not only is the trick so complicated (dare I say: convoluted?) I don't even understand the hint on the title page: on top of that, the puzzle is saturated with trivia. I've had 30 lookups, if not more, I've checked what I've entered so far, and I've used several reveals - but I'm still nowhere near figuring the puzzle out.

I know I am not the sharpest tool in the shed, but I've never struggled as much with a NYT crossword as I am with this one.

Could it possibly be a tad overcooked?

I think I'll just reveal it, shrug at it and move on. So much for a bit of Sunday fun...

I loved it. Early on I thought I might lose my streak bc of the puzzle, but then it came together. It still took quite a long time. I got hung up on BUENOSAIRE([A]/SARGENT)INA  for awhile thinking wAIF instead of NAÏF but it all worked out. Thanks Mr. Kwong!

Yikes, this puzzle hurt my brain. There was just no way to keep track of everything easily on a mobile device. Way too confusing and made attempting to solve too messy and difficult. A puzzle I think that was created for the enjoyment of the constructor….not the solvers.

Ok. Well I guess I see what happened. My final attempt at being done had my puzzle looking like the answer key (which is incorrect?). And as usual for a Sunday I had forgotten to check the title, which of course meant I didn’t have the necessary instructions. At some point I just chose to reveal the puzzle, which made me even more confused. I read the article and then many of the comments and now kind of get what I should have done (left the down letters and just percolated on how the rebuses I entered made the across answers make sense, without actually entering them). 

I think I was having fun with the rebus entries at first but by the end, there was…

no welcome look in your eyes when I reach for you

It makes me just feel like crying
'Cause baby, something beautiful's dyin'
You lost that lovin' feelin'
Whoa, that lovin' feelin'
You lost that lovin' feelin'
Now it's gone, gone, gone

Like many others, I got into this crossword habit during the lockdowns. It is getting progressively harder to find the time to maintain the habit. This may just push me to decide to stop. There is a clever idea in this puzzle, but….

This puzzle  would have been much better if both of the paired answers lit up when you clicked on one of them.  For example, when you click on 92 across GOYA, 33 across WNKEES highlights.  Why not also have it so that when you click on 33 across WNKEES, 92 across GOYA highlights.
I really liked the concept of this puzzle, but unfortunately the execution made it more complicated than it needed to be. What a mess.

This crossword should have helped find the precise point where a puzzle gimmick becomes annoying. But as an experiment it's poorly controlled, with a lot of confounding variables.

Generally I find rebuses enjoyable, though slightly awkward to enter. While the "This square has a different letter in it for the across and down answer" to be the lowest form of crossword.

This should have been a slightly improved version of the latter (constructing a flimsy, but valid, excuse things). But it also adds a pseudo-rebus into the mix, and leaves incoherent text in the grid. Which kind of cancels out any benefit.

This was a slog. It wasn’t hard—these were artists everyone knows and the “trick” was obvious from the moment EASTERN STANDARD TIME didn’t fit and crossed IS?NTO—but it was a slog. Not really much different from other puzzles with rebuses but (a) it’s always annoying when there are rebuses on Sunday’s tiny grid and (b) the rest of the fill was mostly an uninspired, an oversized Monday. 

I’m filing this one under, “Impressive construction feat, more fun for the constructor than the solver.”

I liked the idea of the puzzle but it would have been better if:

1. The highlights worked in both directions. Can’t expect us to remember which word had missing letters. 
2. We did not have the third trick. Especially cumbersome because of 1
3. Crossings were more balanced. Some just didn’t make much sense

I can't imagine how difficult this puzzle must have been to construct. Jaw-droppinglyy brilliant. The last puzzle to awe me like this was a Sunday Texas-hold 'em rebus. 

I don't know my artists, so I only spent a couple of minutes on it before revealing things. But that's just one benefit--there are many, in this gamified world--of refusing to build a streak ;-)

Huge shout-out, by the way, for the ability to reveal words on the e-versions of these puzzles. Lets me enjoy some amazing puzzles that I don't have the time, desire or knowledge to solve. Worth it for the Zamboni puzzle animation alone!

Side note: skimming these comments, I find it odd that apparently, a rebus not reading both ways and "covering up" another letter (part of a nice punchline) is somehow supposed to be a bridge too far... if it's Thursday or Sunday, it's the Wild West, right? I figure rules for puzzles like these are binary: no monkey business, or an arbitrary level of monkey business.
Yikes. I see at least one silver lining here: the next time a puzzle has a 59-word note explaining how it works, I’ll move along right away and save myself a lot of time and frustration.

When I finally polished this one off, I knew this one was going to be hated and the comments do not disappoint:) 

If the thieves had been a bit more professional and hadn't left a letter behind, I think it would have been much more tolerable. The extra trick payoff wasn't worth it (I really couldn't even be bothered to try to track down the extra letters and spell them out, to be honest), and it felt kind of damaging, like when the thieves hacked the Vermeer out of its frame at the Gardiner.

A lot of strong feelings in the comments about this puzzle. I think it helps that I'm relatively new to crosswording so I don't mind if certain conventions (and streaks) are broken. But I agree that it's a lot more pleasing to the eye when the words do cross. There's something very disconcerting about a badly spelled word - like the red dot of an alert. You just want to fix it but you can't. Cue stress.
It’s just not healthy to hate people as much as I do those responsible for this.
I liked it
The only thing stolen here was my time and enjoyment. Glad that one is over.
It would be nice if the links to puzzles in the comments would open in the app instead of the web.
As soon as I understood that “painting” meant “painter,” I found this puzzle to be clever and fun, especially the humor at the end!

i've never seen a puzzle where the rebus letters are completely different from the letter(s) of the cross-word/intersection word.  it's supposed to reflect some kind of slight of hand?  it wasn't magical for me.

Pretty amazing feat of construction. Just a total failure for me. Never figured out exactly how the rebus squares worked; never dawned on me that they could possibly be different in the across and down directions. That just left me baffled in multiple places and I finally just gave up. Quite surprised to see that anyone managed to work this one out. End of streak - no big deal. 

Pretty amazing puzzle find today. I'll put that in a reply. 

...

I only got halfway reading through the "instructions", thought I was reading War and Peace, snapped out of it, and went to the New Yorker's puzzle. I can’t honestly tell if I liked this puzzle or not…
An impressive construction for sure, but not my favorite to solve. 
I don’t think it’s fair to say that the “evidence” squares were unchecked though - they were checked by the phrase “I WAS FRAMED”. I actually needed to use this phrase to figure out the A from MODEL AS and the F from FEMS. At first I had MODEL tS and I could not make any sense of the letters I had left over: IWtS_RAMED, but I knew I must’ve had at least one letter wrong. When the phrase dawned on me I was able to fill in those last two squares and was happy to see the gold star. I was worried I was going to have to spend all day flyspecking this one
I really enjoyed this - I didn't even notice the instructions until I'd finished it so the extra Easter egg was really impressive. More of this sort of thing!
First Ford was a model T, not A.  I wasted half an hour trying to figure out what I had done wrong.

Spent the first half hour cursing the constructor, but when i finally caught on to what he was doing, it was like doing a paint-by-number project...no great work of art but amusing...in spite of a couple of naticks . And i agree with others that the Instructions could have been better edited. Wish VanGogh had been included...one of the greatest painters ever.

I wonder if a puzzle with this many layers was attempted in the pre-digital age. Keeping notes on the side, on paper or electronically if that works better for you, really helped get through it without wasting more time than expected trying to remember which entries were related and which nonsense letters were the placeholders for the stolen “paintings”. We have come to expect the app to handle things like this for us and when it doesn’t we grumble. This was one occasion when solving on paper might actually have been an advantage. 
The gibberish in the solutions made it especially difficult to spot typos and incorrect entries.
I do admire the cleverness of the construction, though.
Once you say, hey, it’s ok if the letters of a crossword don’t actually have to, you know, cross…

Usually I don't look at the title on Sunday or read the note if there is one unless I get desperate.

I got desperate.

Even then, I forgot about the part where you had to read the hidden message.  At the end, looking at 12 D, I thought, "Is this an actual, true Natick?  Did the constructor expect me to know about THE C_?"  Apparently not.  I reread the note, wrote down the message, filled in that W and was done.  

Thanks for a wild ride, David.
Swing and a miss on this one. Seeding the puzzle with ten unchecked letters just makes it a sort of Super-Natick and more chore than fun for the solver. I miss Will.

Easily one of my favorite crosswords of all time. Fantastic job! Any naysayers in the comments did not think outside of the box (no pun intended). I am no crossword expert by any means and I managed this one just fine. I think the instructions were a bit confusing for some people--I too didn't follow at first.

It was great! It pushed me further outside of my box, and that's the point, isn't it?  I needed a little spreadsheet to track the order of the evidence letters.  Without that I would have had to use a pencil (with eraser) and paper.  And when I earned the gold star it was brighter and much more satisfying than usual.  

I think the complainers sometimes lack the patience to try new things, some of which are old.
Maybe to make things easier for those who had difficulty with the puzzle’s format, should we just say that, with 10 unchecked squares, this wasn't a “crossword” puzzle?
Nice try, but I can't be bothered.

Here to add my voice to the chorus. 

Even if the triBk clues had been bilaterally croAs-referenced (why on earth did you decide not to do that?!), the faDt that the "stolen lePter" seemed entirely random still would have made this a frustratUng puzzle to solve (aZthough I'd probably be far less anZoyed if the clues hLd at least been bilaterally cEoss-referenced).

Finished, but over 20% slower than my average time. Agree with commenters' complaints about failing to cross-reference linked clues. The completed puzzle just looks bizarre due to the "clever" phrase being shoehorned in with no regard to sense or symmetry. A frustrating experience.

I come here to do a crossword on my tablet, not a white board. This is a great construction, but belongs somewhere else on the game page. Not fun, good-bye streak, don't want to sit at a 22 inch monitor with a legal pad and pencil.
Yikes that was bad.

Pity the digital solver. Don’t make us print it out and scrounge around for a pen to circle the hidden letter clues or mark which artist went with which long answer it was stolen from. I’m in bed in the middle of the night. It’s cold. I don’t want to get up. But I’ve got a 200 day streak going so I’ve GOT to. Okay maybe I’ll try using the Notes app. But then when I click on one of the artists, it shows me the longer phrase from which it was stolen. Why can’t it do the same thing the other way around? Why do I have to go searching for the artist’s name? Try to keep the process fun, okay? Btw, some lesbians are fem and some aren’t. It has nothing to do with whether they are part of a couple.

I enjoyed this puzzle until I got massively bogged down in Saturday level clues, alternate spellings, and awkward abbreviations. The plural of KM is KM. The abbreviation for crescendo is CRESC. AXLED DIALOG IRISED FLAM were not pleasant to solve. The rebuses were clever but too tricky to suss out their location. In the end I finished but by then I was just irritated instead of satisfied. It could have been more fun if the cluing has been better and some of the worst crosswordese avoided.

Not a lot of love in the comments today.  I enjoyed this because I'm always looking for a challenge as well as something different.  That said, solving this online must have been a real bear.  On paper, it was easy to keep track.  When I got to 8 A, I went down 
and circled 71 A and wrote a little 8 A next to it.  It still took some time, but kept it from becoming a frustrating experience.

I'm sorry for everyone who had a miserable time with this because it really was quite clever.  For many people, it apparently didn't translate well for an online solve.
Joining the unhappy chorus. Finished, but not satisfied -- too clever by half.

I got the trick on my own, which I was proud of, except that it never occurred to me that one square in each theme entry would have a letter from the crossing entry only. I just assumed that the extra letter was a repeated letter that, for some reason, hadn’t been “stolen.” It took me the longest time to solve and I ended up having to resort to puzzle checking to figure out what I was doing wrong. 

Entries that I had no clue on, like SMACTS, TITER, and OLIOS, didn’t help to clear up the confusion. 

Got my brain working on a Sunday morning, so I can’t be too frustrated about it!

This was so much fun! I didn't read the instructions at the top, was confused by the errant letters, and decided they must spell out something. I actually laughed out loud when I pieced them together! Solving the print edition made this easier, after I wrote notes to put clue pairs together.

Well done!
I just loved this one. Figured out the theme and still had enough to keep it entertaining. This how puzzles should be. Puzzles.

Disappointed to start my morning with this instead of the usual enjoyable Sunday puzzle.   Whatever this is, it's not a crossword.   Okay, maybe *half* of it is a crossword.  The other half is something I'm (apparently along with a lot of people) not at all interested in. 

I thought things like this were relegated to Thursdays.  Please keep them there.

I know people are in at least two camps on crosswords that add puzzling elements that make them non-traditional crosswords. I’m in the camp that loves finding one like this that’s doing something quite out of the ordinary, and I don’t read solving notes in advance, so I worked it without the awareness that it was going to be trickier than usual. Though there was a LOT of having to keep track of things, my feelings about that were ultimately outweighed by the ahas (including SMOKEEFECTS and I WAS FRAMED). I had the same wish expressed by other commenters that the clue highlighting was bi-directional. I also think I would have found it more fun to have the frames that showed up around the I WAS FRAMED letters at the end be visible from the beginning. Having that art museum aesthetic would have added a nice visual element, while also making it easier to keep track of where I was inserting things, and—having put the idea of frames in my mind—might have enabled me  to use that great phrase as an actual cross-check of those tricky squares during the solving process, and simultaneously eliminating the not fun job of hunting for the letters that I’d entered in pencil format or left blank in order to figure out what they were supposed to spell. Thanks, David and editors, for a good challenge!
That was amazing! Don't know how he made it all work. WOW--thanks!

The best part of this puzzle was that Navy won the Army/Navy game yesterday. Doesn't make sense? Well neither did including letters in the down answers that weren't part of the across answers, especially in a Sunday puzzle.
